titleproper.value:
Guide to the New-York Historical Society Audiovisual Media Record Group
                    <lb/> 1974-2002
                    <lb/>
                    <num>NYHS-RG 28</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Margaret Kaczorowski

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2017-05-22T14:29-0400</date>

unittitle.value: New-York Historical Society audiovisual media records

extent.value: in nine record cartons and eight document boxes.

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: The New-York Historical Society audiovisual media records primarily include videocassettes and audiocassettes from the late 1980s to early 1990s. N-YHS’s lectures, panel discussions and concerts organized around the “Why History?” theme (1990-92) and programs connected to the bicentennial of the U.S. Constitution (1987) are especially well-documented, though many other presentations in video or audio format are also included. Audiotapes include training for docents and N-YHS education staff concerning particular N-YHS exhibitions and gallery installations. The record group is currently restricted because of the lack of appropriate playback equipment and the fragility of the tapes.

p.value: The record group is restricted. The record group includes audiovisual formats that are either too fragile to play or do not have the necessary playback equipment available or both.
This record group should be cited as New-York Historical Society audiovisual media records (NYHS-RG 28), The New-York Historical Society.

The record group includes audiovisual formats, primarily videocassettes and audiocassettes, that were found in the archive as standalone objects. (Audiovisual formats found in exhibition or other files remain in those files in other record groups.) These formats date principally from the late 1980s to early 1990s, though there are some into the early 2000s. The subject matter of the videotapes includes mostly public programs, especially the “Why History?” lectures and panel discussions of 1990-1992. Educational programs, public service announcements, exhibition openings, and some History Makers award events have videos. Audiotapes also include programs, such as “Why History?,” but also have a broader range of topics, including docent and education staff training for exhibitions and gallery installations. Programs related to the exhibition 
                <emph render="italic">Government by Choice: Inventing the U.S. Constitution</emph> and other initiatives connected to the bicentennial of the Constitution in 1987 are well-represented in the record group. The record group is currently restricted because of the lack of appropriate playback equipment and the fragility of the tapes.

subject.value: Learned institutions and societies -- New York (State) -- New York
Museum docents -- New York (State) -- New York

dsc.value:
Series I. Moving Images 8.3 Linear feet 1985-2002 Arrangement Note

The container list includes an inventory of items in sequential box order. The items appear to have been fitted into boxes in no particular order and the inventory reflects that.

The subject descriptions and dates used in the container list were taken from the labels on the item. [Bracketed] descriptions were added by the processing archivist. The formats (e.g., VHS, Betacam) noted in the container list were determined by the archivist’s observations; where the archivist was uncertain of the format, the description “format?” was used.

 Scope and Contents Note

The series includes moving image formats, primarily videocassettes in VHS, Betacam, and U-Matic formats. The bulk of these date from the late 1980s and early 1990s and, judging only from the labels, the subject matter primarily concerns programs held at N-YHS. Most extensively documented in these tapes are the lectures, panel discussions and some concerts presented as part of the “Why History?” series that ran from 1990-92. These series linked various programs to particular themes, including “Race and Class” in 1991 and “What is American?” in 1992. Educational initiatives are also documented here, including high school student mock Constitutional Convention debates, the Liberty Scholars partnership with Bank Street College, and the Lab School collaboration with I.S. 44.

The moving images also include public service announcements (PSAs), interviews, and exhibition openings. Many of these relate to N-YHS’s exhibition Government by Choice: Inventing the U.S. Constitution and other tie-ins to the bicentennial of the Constitution in 1987. Tapes of special events are also included, such as some of the History Makers Award ceremonies (including the second one, in 1989, honoring Malcolm Forbes) and former President Bill Clinton’s July 2001 appearance.

 NHK-TV Japan: Advanced English Conversation with Betsy Gotbaum 15 1 1995 Scope and Contents Note

Includes a VHS videocassette of the Gotbaum interview that aired in Japan, and a companion booklet to the video with an English transcription under the title, "Making Historical Objects Accessible and Exciting." The booklet also includes a transcription of an interview with N-YHS Curator of Architectural Collections Mary Beth Betts on the topic of "Photographs as History."

 Series II. Audiotapes 3.46 Linear feet 1974-1991 Arrangement Note

The container list includes an inventory of items in sequential box order. The items appear to have been fitted into boxes in no particular order and the inventory reflects that.

The subject descriptions and dates used in the container list were taken from the labels on the item. [Bracketed] descriptions were added by the processing archivist.

 Scope and Contents Note

The series includes audiocassette tapes (and a few open reels and a tape cartridge) dating primarily from the late 1980s and early 1990s. Judging only from the labels, the subject matter appears to primarily include public lectures and presentations held at N-YHS and training/background sessions, likely for docents, educators and other N-YHS staff responsible for conveying exhibition interpretative comments to the public. Many of the tapes include the lectures, panel discussions and some concerts presented as part of the “Why History?” series that ran from 1990-92. Other tapes include lectures by guest speakers and N-YHS curators that related to exhibitions, including those by N-YHS museum curator Annette Blaugrund on Paris 1889 (1989) and The Taste of Andrew Carnegie (1991), N-YHS Librarian James Mooney on Putting New York on the Map (1988), and Professor Mosette Broderick on McKim, Mead & White's New York (1991), to name just a few. Tapes related to docent training include, among many others, museum curator Ella Foshay on the Niagara (1986) and Hudson River School (1987) exhibitions, curator Tim Burgard on Thomas Cole’s The Course of Empire (1989), and N-YHS educators Carole Slatkin and Jane Lattes on Audubon (1987) and firefighting (1985) exhibitions, respectively. Some tapes provide collection overviews, including an “Introduction to Department of Public Programs: Highlights for Teachers” (1986) and Ella Foshay on “Treasures of the New-York Historical Society” (1988). Many tapes related to programs connected to the bicentennial of the Constitution are found in the series, including guest curator Betsy McCaughey on the exhibition Government by Choice: Inventing the U.S. Constitution (1987) and the series of educational programs broadcast on radio.

(Cartridge, tape) 15 5 1974 October 30 Scope and Contents Note

Tape reel # U-683. Interview of Heslin by WNYC/93.9 FM/TV/31. Aired January 1975.

 Government by Choice PSAs (open reel, tape) 16 2 1987 September 14 Scope and Contents Note

Label for 7 1/2 ips ft mono reads :30 & :60 PSA's for N-YHS's "Government By Choice."

 N-YHS Adult/Child Narrative (4 open reels, tape) 17 - 1987 March 10 Scope and Contents Note

This is likely the introduction to N-YHS and its collections produced in 1986-87. Consists of four open reels with the identifying number S-7761 on each. There are three 15 feet reels labeled Outs (Dolby), Pulsed Mixes (Endless Loop), and Adult/Child Slide Narration. One reel is labeled Mix 7 Voice 5. 3 reels appear to be audio; the fourth is uncertain and might be the slides to accompany the narrative.

 The Great Experiment / Constitution Slide Show (3 open reels, tape) 17 - 1987 September 11 Scope and Contents Note

Consists of three open reels with the identifying number T-9912 on each. The reels are labeled N-YHS Constitution 'Outs', "Constitution" Narrative Pulsed, and the third is labeled "The Great Experiment" and contains a typed script with annotations. The first two reels are audio; the third is uncertain but might be the slide show.

 Series III. Digital Media 0.36 Linear feet circa 1980s-2002 Arrangement Note

The items are in no particular arrangement.

 Scope and Contents Note

The series includes a small number of digital formats. The most useful is the 2002 DVD concerning a tribute to N-YHS honorees Colin and Nancy Campbell. The bulk of the series includes 5-1/4 inch floppy disks, many of which appear to be operating system or other software applications for personal computers.

 In Trust to America: A Tribute to Colin and Nancy Campbell 15 2 2002 Scope and Contents Note

Produced by the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation, this 9 minute DVD film celebrates the awarding of the N-YHS's DeWitt Clinton Medal to the Campbells. DVD features Society President Kenneth T. Jackson and was screened at the History Makers Gala in 2002.

 The Making of Alice in Wonderland 15 3 [2009] General Note

Disk contains the numbers 2009.39 and 2009.40, possible Museum object numbers.

 Backup Multi Lotus Inventory (8 floppy disks) 15 4 undated Scope and Contents Note

Consists of 5-1/4 inch disks. Disks appear to be software programs and are individually labeled Formatted DSK 31-34, Backup System Backup, PC Tools Backup, and DOS 3.2.

 Software Etc. (10 floppy disks) 15 - circa 1980s? Scope and Contents Note

Consists of 5-1/4 inch disks. Several disks are labeled as Invoices, D-Base, Whi and Mo Bkup.The remainder are unlabeled.

 Documents (9 floppy disks) 16 1 Before Fiscal Year 1993 Scope and Contents Note

Consists of 5 1/4 inch disks. Disks are individually labled as: N-YHS Emergency Plan Draft, Labels/Exhibition, Technical Services Job Description, Correspondence, and Budget Table.
